title: Introduction
content: Welcome to DeFi Scholar!# The What and Why of DeFi# DeFi is short for “DeCentralized Finance” For aspiring finance majors, studying DeFi is essential because it represents the programmable future of money, thereby equipping students to thrive in an industry where traditional barriers are crumbling in favor of transparent, efficient systems “If you’re not looking at DeFi you’re not going to make it in finance” Approach# “Learn together” - this guide is by high schoolers for high schoolers Keeping things simple and using examples Explain basics and leave deep dives for projects or future study

title: Basic Terminology
content: Networks# A lot of material is going to be about networks In the blockchain/de-fi world a network is either a bunch of computers - proper servers, but also phones and tables and such or a bunch of people who use these computers to trade, mine, bet and such These people or computers are referred to as “nodes” Blockchain# Blockchain is the name of technology - computer programs executing bunch of well-known algorithm Bitcoin, Ethereum, Solana are different networks that use Blockchain Each of these networks uses a specific token - Bitcoin is a token, the NFTs, mem coins, stablecoins - all these > things are tokens Some of the algorithms have to with cryptography, which is why the people refer to blockchain tokens as > “crypto-currency” or just “crypto” P2P (peer to peer) and “De” in DeFi# Blockchain is a peer-to-peer network; all peers are equals - they have the same rights on the network No central authority = DEcentralized network This is where the “De” in De-Fi coming from The “FI” in DeFi# The networks we just mentioned allow people to create apps that use tokens to do “proper” finance activities - running exchanges, trading, lending, earning fees and such - hence “Fi” in De-Fi So you now have a decentralized network of equal peers Anyone can create an app and anyone can use apps Which is really why the opportunities of De-Fi are limitless
